Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Situation2: Early in their career, they have not yet saved enough for travel.
Story:
Every day at my telemarketing job, I dial number after number, my headset pressing into my ears as I recite the script about our new service. The script is supposed to guide me, but lately, more and more prospects ask technical questions I can’t answer. My supervisor expects me to handle objections smoothly, to keep the conversation going, but I feel exposed when I stumble over details I don’t know. I want to do well, to keep this job, because I need the income.

But as a Muslim, I also carry the weight of another expectation: to perform Hajj. My parents remind me gently, and I feel it in my prayers—the longing to fulfill this pillar of my faith. Yet, I’m early in my career, barely making enough to cover rent and groceries, let alone save for the pilgrimage. Each time I hear the call to prayer, I feel the tension tighten inside me. I want to be a good employee, to meet my supervisor’s demands, but I also want to be a good Muslim, to answer the call of Hajj. The two roles pull at me, and I sit at my desk, torn, unsure which expectation I can meet first.
